xxl.core.collections.queues
Class ListQueue<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.queues.AbstractQueue<E>
      xxl.core.collections.queues.ListQueue<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements of this queue.
All Implemented Interfaces:
FIFOQueue<E>, Queue<E>
public class ListQueue<E>
extends AbstractQueue<E>
implements FIFOQueue<E>

This class provides an implementation of the Queue interface with a FIFO (first in, first out) strategy that internally uses a list to store its elements. It implements the peek method.

The performance of the queue depends on the performance of the internally used list (e.g., an ArrayList guarantees for insertion in amortized constant time, that is, adding n elements requires O(n) time).

Usage example (1). 

     // create a new list queue (that uses a linked list to store its elements per default)
 
     ListQueue<Integer> queue = new ListQueue<Integer>();

     // open the queue

     queue.open();

     // create an iteration over 20 random Integers (between 0 and 100)

     Cursor<Integer> cursor = new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(100), 20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator

     for (; cursor.hasNext(); queue.enqueue(cursor.next()));

     // print all elements of the queue

     while (!queue.isEmpty())
         System.out.println(queue.dequeue());
     System.out.println();

     // close the open queue and cursor after use
     
     queue.close();
     cursor.close();
Usage example (2). 
     // create an iteration over 20 random Integers (between 0 and 100)

     cursor = new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(100), 20);
 
     // create a new list queue that uses an array list to store its
     // elements and that contains all elements of the given iterator

     queue = new ListQueue<Integer>(new java.util.ArrayList<Integer>());
     
     // open the queue
   
     queue.open();
     
     // insert all elements into the queue
 
     for (; cursor.hasNext(); queue.enqueue(cursor.next()));

     // print all elements of the queue
     
     while (!queue.isEmpty())
          System.out.println(queue.dequeue());
     System.out.println();

     // close the open queue and cursor after use

     queue.close();
     cursor.close();

See Also:
Queue, AbstractQueue, FIFOQueue

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function<Object,ListQueue<Object>> FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a new ListQueue (see contract for FACTORY_METHOD in interface Queue). It may be invoked with a parameter list (for further details see Function) of lists, an iterator or without any parameters. A parameter list of lists will be used to initialize the internally used list with the list at index 0 and an iterator will be used to insert the contained elements into the new ListQueue.

See Also:
Function

list

protected List<E> list
The list is internally used to store the elements of the queue.

Constructor Detail

ListQueue

public ListQueue(List<E> list)
Constructs a queue containing the elements of the list. The specified list is internally used to store the elements of the queue.

Parameters:
list - the list that is used to initialize the internally used list.

ListQueue

public ListQueue()
Constructs an empty queue. This queue instantiates a new LinkedList in order to store its elements.

Returns:
the next element in the queue.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all of the elements from this queue. The queue will be empty after this call returns so that size() == 0.
Note that the elements will only be removed from the queue but not from the underlying collection.

Specified by:
clear in interface Queue<E>
Overrides:
clear in class AbstractQueue<E>

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples how to use a ListQueue. It can also be used to test the functionality of a ListQueue.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
